tiled.view
Class HexMapView

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              javax.swing.JPanel
                  tiled.view.MapView
                      tiled.view.HexMapView
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.Scrollable
public class HexMapView
extends MapView

A View for displaying Hex based maps. There are four possible layouts for the hexes. These are called tile alignment and are named 'top', 'bottom', 'left' and 'right'. The name designates the border where the first row or column of hexes is aligned with a flat side. I.e. 'left' and 'right' result in hexes with the pointy sides up and down and the first row either aligned left or right: 

   /\
  |  |
   \/
And 'top' and 'bottom' result in hexes with the pointy sides to the left and right and the first column either aligned top or bottom: 
   __
  /  \
  \__/

Here is an example 2x2 map with top alignment: 

   ___
  /0,0\___
  \___/1,0\
  /0,1\___/
  \___/1,1\
      \___/

The icon width and height refer to the total width and height of a hex (i.e the size of the enclosing rectangle).

Version:
$Id$

Method Detail

getScrollableBlockIncrement

public int getScrollableBlockIncrement(java.awt.Rectangle visibleRect,
                                       int orientation,
                                       int direction)
The scroll increment when clicking in the trough of a scrollbar, that is scrolling a page. The amount is set to the size of the completely visible hexes in the viewport.

Specified by:
getScrollableBlockIncrement in interface javax.swing.Scrollable
Specified by:
getScrollableBlockIncrement in class MapView
Parameters:
visibleRect - Current viewport rectangle.
orientation - SwingConstants.VERTICAL or HORIZONTAL.
direction - > 0 = scrolling down; < 0 = scrolling up.
Returns:
Scroll amount in pixels.

getEffectiveTileSize

private java.awt.Dimension getEffectiveTileSize()
Returns:
The tile size in the view without border as Dimension.

getThreeQuarterHex

private int getThreeQuarterHex()
Together with getOneQuarterHex this gives the sizes of one and three quarters in pixels in the interesting dimension. If the layout is such that the hex edges point left and right the interesting dimension is the width, otherwise it is the height. The sum of one and three quarters equals always the total size of the hex in this dimension.

Returns:
Three quarter of the tile size width or height (see above) as integer.

getOneQuarterHex

private int getOneQuarterHex()
Together with getThreeQuarterHex this gives the sizes of one and three quarters in pixels in the interesting dimension. If the layout is such that the hex edges point left and right the interesting dimension is the width, otherwise it is the height. The sum of one and three quarters equals always the total size of the hex in this dimension.

Returns:
One quarter of the tile size width or height (see above) as integer.

screenToTileCoords

public java.awt.Point screenToTileCoords(int screenX,
                                         int screenY)
Compute the resulting tile coords, i.e. map coordinates, from a point in the viewport. This function works for some coords off the map, i.e. it works for the tile coord -1 and for coords larger than the map size.

Specified by:
screenToTileCoords in class MapView
Parameters:
screenX - The x coordinate of a point in the viewport.
screenY - The y coordinate of a point in the viewport.
Returns:
The corresponding tile coords as Point.

tileToScreenCoords

public java.awt.Point tileToScreenCoords(int x,
                                         int y)
Returns the location (center) on screen for the given tile. Works also for hypothetical tiles off the map. The zoom is accounted for.

Specified by:
tileToScreenCoords in class MapView
Parameters:
x - The x coordinate of the tile.
y - The y coordinate of the tile.
Returns:
The point at the centre of the Hex as Point.

screenToPixelCoords

public java.awt.Point screenToPixelCoords(int x,
                                          int y)
Description copied from class: MapView
Returns the pixel coordinates on the map based on the given screen coordinates. The map pixel coordinates may be different in more ways than the zoom level, depending on the projection the view implements.

Specified by:
screenToPixelCoords in class MapView
Parameters:
x - x in screen coordinates
y - y in screen coordinates
Returns:
the position in map pixel coordinates
